question: Used to.
answer: What's the matter? It was good.

question: Everybody there's going to be good, Mom. I have to be better. My knees still knock when I do my free form. Did you notice that?
answer: I noticed that it was fine.

question: It's not supposed to be fine. It's supposed to be special. And it just lays there, it doesn't do anything. I bet they notice that. That it doesn't do anything. That I don't do anything special enough to get in.
answer: Sara. You'll get in.

question: Don't lie because you love me. My free form sucks.
answer: I've got something for you. Come on. Sit. Mouth closed, eyes shut. No pouting. No peeking. For luck tomorrow. Not that you'll need it. You dance like an angel.

question: I love the necklace but you're still the best luck I'll ever have. Oh. It's a good luck charm. Doesn't always work. Lindsay... no. Not here.
answer: Where'd you get those, traitor?

question: Ellison -- Mr. Ellison. He actually told me to break a leg.
answer: Roses from the principal, even droopy, out-of-season yellow ones, is beyond cool, kiddo. You're definitely movin' up in the world.

question: Know what would be great? If you didn't drop me off at the bus station. If we just kept going until we get to Philly.
answer: Ruin everyone's Valentine's Day and not have a shop when I get back. That's your definition of great? I can see the headline now

question: Right. This is the hardest, most important day of my life and all you can do is get there as soon as you can. Thanks, Mom. So I guess I'll see you later.
answer: I won't miss your audition, Sara. I'll be there, okay? If I have to swim the Susquehanna, I'll be there.

question: Swim? You can't swim, Mom.
answer: I'll float then. Hey... Happy Valentine's Day.

question: Well, it's um, pretty self- explanatory. The theme. Thank you.
answer: Hi.

question: Hi.
answer: Have a good ride?

question: Slept through most of it.
answer: Guess you got stuff. Baggage.

question: Two suitcases. One big one.
answer: Looks like they're unloading. -- You hungry? We can stop somewhere if you want.

question: I'm kinda tired.
answer: I didn't like leavin' you so soon after the funeral. I wouldn't have if you hadn't asked me to go. I mean, I could've hung around. Helped you say good-bye. That's what you were doin', wasn't it?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: That's what I figured you were doin'. Look. Sara. I feel bad too. I mean, we both got hit by the same bolt of lightning. You don't have to pretend this is easy. Everything's upside down right now but don't worry. We'll work this bachelor-father thing out. Hell, it ain't like we're movin' in with strangers. We got a pretty good idea about each other, right?

question: Thought you were moving to Fells Point.
answer: Fell through. Not much of what you're used to. But the water's hot and the fridge is full. And I made room in the closets for you. Girl's gotta have closets, right? You even get your own bed. I'll crash on the couch.

question: You bought a bed?
answer: Pardon me. Your own futon. Check it out. On the other side.

question: Do you have a phone?
answer: Of course I have a phone.

question: You didn't at the last place. The last place I saw anyway.
answer: Things change. You've changed. You grew up on me. Overnight.

question: Over the summer. You blew me off for some gig on the road, remember? Can I call Lindsay? Let her know I got here alright.
answer: Are you alright, Sara? I just wanna know how you feel.

question: I feel fine. I feel like calling Lindsay.
answer: Phone's in the kitchen. Knock yourself out.

question: I can take the school bus. Tomorrow.
answer: School bus? That's the other Oz, Dorothy. Patterson kids ride the city Metro. Or walk.

question: Well, I know how to do both.
answer: Not around here you don't. Not until you get the hang of things. I called about your transcripts. You're all set. Patterson's got a pretty good Humanities program. No ballet, but we can find a studio someplace close for after school --

question: -- I don't think I'll have time. I have to study, I'll be busy.
answer: Good idea. Take a break. Not too long a break though. You're a dancer. You should dance. Stay on top of your art.

question: Like you stay on top of yours?
answer: Maybe I ain't playin' no grand ballrooms or fancy jazz festivals, but I'm playing.

question: I didn't mean it like that.
answer: S'alright. Hell, I wish I had half the time I wasted gettin' wasted. But those days are over. You'll see. I got my life on track.

question: You don't have to go in with me. Since I'm all set. I mean, I have done this before. Gone to school. I'll be fine. I am fine. Really.
answer: -- Pick you up. Three-thirty.

question: Yeah. Sure. Whatever.
answer: Any questions? Concerns?

question: About school? No. Not really.
answer: Not even about Baltimore?

question: It's a non-fiction novel. The first of its kind. Capote mixed true events with things he couldn't know, so he made them up.
answer: White folks back then felt safe. Capote scared 'em. He took hard core crime out the ghetto and dropped it in America's back yard. That's what makes the book special.

question: Yeah. That is part of it.
answer: That's all of it. Capote wasn't first. Richard Wright and James Baldwin did the same thing. Wasn't nobody tryin' to read them though.

question: Lots of people read them.
answer: Lots of people like who? You? Hello. Didn't think so.

question: Sara. It's Sara.
answer: Yeah. It's Sara. And you're boring her from the ears down. You finished?

question: God! Thank you!
answer: Gotta watch where you sit, girl. And it's Chenille. But you're still welcome. Let's catch some air before the bell rings.

question: What's it called? What she's doing?
answer: A dance.

question: Asshole.
answer: Asshole beaucoup. In this crowd, you gotta be more specific.

question: He's in one of my classes. Thinks he's so... smart. So cute.
answer: I don't know about cute but he is smart. Real smart. Real trip, too.

question: So you know him?
answer: Patrick Reynolds? Hell yeah, I know him. He's my brother.

question: Shut the fuck up and step your lame ass off, Snookie. You heard me. Space.
answer: What happened to you at lunch, man?

question: Business.
answer: So you're hangin' in, man? Feelin' strong about being back?

question: Not at this motherfucker. Out a week and where am I? Fucking home sweet high school. Jail away from jail. You can have it.
answer: You gonna stay though. Right?

question: Judge says it's school or JuVee and I sure as hell ain't goin' back there. Shit. I never knew a year could be such a long time.
answer: You up for some hoops after school? Break your free-throw back in. Chump the chumps like we used to.

question: How'd it go?
answer: Fine. Tomorrow I catch the bus.

question: Hey, Sara. C'mere a minute.
answer: What?

question: Just come here. Hungry and Healthys. I asked at the market. They're the best. So. What do you feel like? Lamb Chop Suey? Tropical Tuna? Primavera Paradise?
answer: I had a big lunch.

question: What do you wanna do? You wanna hang out with me? Go to my gig. You can if you want.
answer: It's a school night, Roy.

question: I need a date --
answer: Why? Your hand busy?

question: -- For the prom. And if it wasn't for that kinda undue attitude, you could be the lucky girl, Chenille. My personal prom queen. I can see us now.
answer: You must be lookin' in your dreams.

question: That's too big.
answer: I know it's too big.

question: I wouldn't do that if I were you.
answer: Who died and made you teacher?

question: Girl, how you get your legs to twist like that?
answer: Yeah. What was all that double- jointed cheerleader shit?

question: This is Diggy. Thinks she's down.
answer: Egg-cuse me? I am down.

question: That's okay. I dance in circles. Probably around you.
answer: I'm splittin'. Whatcha readin'?

question: Chemistry.
answer: You're takin' chemistry?

question: Right now it's taking me.
answer: Give yourself some time. Well. See ya in the mornin'. Maybe I'll call between sets.

question: I'll be asleep. Cool outfit.
answer: Slammin'. Slammin' outfit.

question: ... I look okay?
answer: Yeah. You look okay. Moma Dean. I'm leavin'. Grandmom, Sara. Sara, Grandmom. Also known as Momma Dean. And handsome here is Christopher.

question: Hi. Is that... is he... yours?
answer: He sure ain't Momma Dean's. ... He'll be one in July. Best mistake I ever made. Kenny -- Christopher's father -- he's the worst. Triflin'. Okay?

question: Chenille. She's ugly. She's fat!
answer: She's twenty-one too. I ain't got all night. Let's hop.

question: Wait. I have to ask you something. Do I really look alright?
answer: Gimme that '89 Madonna shit. Your jacket. Give it here.

question: It's from the GAP.
answer: It's country. You look country in it. Take it off.

question: I'm not walking in there in my bra.
answer: Rope dopes. C'mon. Too fine to stand in line?

question: Can't get much more underground than this.
answer: Let's get our table 'fore it gets crashed and I hafta hurt somebody.

question: What are you, some kind of V.I.P.?
answer: Snook hooks me up whenever he dees. Got what? The right to walk past your greasy, tickle dick self without your paws on my ass? 'S'that how I got it? That's how I thought I had it. See ya.

question: 'Cause I can't stand her ass and the way she played my brother. I need a drink, Sara. Let's walk. That's him. Comin' over. Kenny? Don't look.
answer: What's up?

question: Where's my money, Kenny?
answer: I'm a little short this week. Don't jump off. It's comin'.

question: It's comin'? No. You lyin'.
answer: Lemme rap to you about the situation on the dance floor.

question: Let's dance.
answer: Let's not.

question: Oh? It's gonna be like that.
answer: How'd you think it was gonna be? That you was gonna drop me and pick me up whenever you felt like it?

question: It ain't all that serious, Patrick.
answer: It ain't anymore, Nikki. Not to me.

question: It ain't anymore, Nikki. Not to me.
answer: Rum and Coke, straight up. And a beer. I don't care. Anything.

question: Bad choice. 'Anything.'
answer: It's just a beer.

question: Then it should be the best beer. You'd know that if you really drank.
answer: Whatever.

question: What's that mean? Whatever.
answer: Whatever you want it to mean. You're the whiz kid, right? You know everything.

question: Not everything. Like I don't know why we're standin' still. I'm supposed to be dizzy by now. Remember? From all those circles you danced around me.
answer: I don't feel like dancing.

question: But you do know how...?
answer: Would I be here if I didn't?

question: pummeling his dealer into cowering submission. Only then does he look over at Malakai who, eyes engorged with rage, is standing over his opponent, kicking and stomping him with no signs of letting up. Patrick can see Malakai's too far gone for talk. He rushes him from behind, nearly lifts Malakai off his feet to swing him away from the dealer's writhing body on the floor. Man, what the hell are you doin'? Tryin' to get sent back up?
answer: They the ones tryin' shit. Comin' here. Squarin' off in my shit.

question: You couldn't let it slide?
answer: Let it slide tonight, they come back strong tomorrow. You know that.

question: Malakai, you fuck up parole, you ain't gonna back to JuVee. Eighteen and up, that's Jessup. Hardcore lockdown. You want that?
answer: I want what was mine. Feetz is my spot. I'ma do business here just like I did before. Like we did before. And if I gotta stomp some niggers in my way, so be it.

question: Well, you definitely got the stompin' part down.
answer: We fucked those fools up for sure.

question: It's not okay, okay? Come on, Braveheart. What?
answer: What?

question: Why you keep lookin' at me?
answer: I have to look somewhere. The streets are deserted. Might as well look at you.

question: That's not why. You wanna know somethin'. Ask somethin'.
answer: It's not a question. It's the way you were beating that kid up. You looked so mad.

question: I was mad and he wasn't no kid. But you're from the suburb Mars, right? Folks don't fight there.
answer: Not like that. You were really kicking his ass. Are you laughing at me?

question: My friend was in trouble.
answer: Maybe he's my question. Your friend. Chenille doesn't like him.

question: She likes him. It don't stop her from trippin' off him now and then. But Malakai's good people. We go back. Way back. You know, like they say, through thick and thin. So, how'd you like Feetz?
answer: It was great.

question: Once you got used to the music.
answer: It wasn't the music I wasn't used to. I mean, it's not the first time I heard hip-hop, Patrick.

question: Uh-huh. Bet you listen to it all the time.
answer: Not all the time. But a lot.

question: We gettin' any closer to your crib or should we stop for food and water?
answer: We passed it.

question: You passed it.
answer: Thanks for walking me.

question: No problem.
answer: So. I'll see ya.

question: Is that 'see ya' like gee-whiz, had a great time, can't wait to see you again? Or is it like 'see ya,' I'll bust a cap in your ass if you ever darken my doorstep again?
answer: I haven't said gee-whiz since I was six. But I really had a great time... okay?

question: Figured I'd put a little marrow in your bones. Siddown, siddown. You gettin' along at school? Makin' friends...? ... See any of 'em last night? I came home on my break.
answer: Oh.

question: ... Oh? Jesus! You're hard! Look. You're seventeen. If you wanna go out, go out. But don't lie to me. On top of everything else, don't make me worry like that about you. I didn't mean to yell. So how are the eggs? They good?
answer: You're right. I should've said something. I'm sorry.

question: What're you gonna do today? Anything special?
answer: Nope. Nothing special.

question: ... How you know I can't do nothin' for you? I'm the hardest workin' man in showbizness, girl. C'mon. Let me be the bomb in your shell.
answer: You do the shit to yourself, man. The bomb in your shell?

question: That was black magic, Patrick. It's gonna work one of these days. Last one on the rack. I snatched it up for you. Rang it up on my discount.
answer: Thank you, Snookie.

question: You workin' or what, man?
answer: On my way. Soon as I get outta here... Throwin' a party?

question: On my way. Soon as I get outta here... Throwin' a party?
answer: Just adding to my collection. I heard some stuff I didn't have last night.

question: Well, you were fly anyway. Last night. Dancin', I mean.
answer: Not as fly as you.

question: Nobody's as fly as me.
answer: Not yet anyway.

question: Maybe we could hook up later. After school or somethin'. Work on some of your moves. If you want.
answer: Okay. Sure.

question: By the way, Hammer's pretty much played out.
answer: Not to me. It was so... slamming, Lindsay. The dancing! I'm going again. What? No, I haven't seen anybody get shot yet. God, I didn't move to Bosnia. What happened?

question: I don't know what to say. I don't.
answer: How 'bout fuck it? Or should I say fuck her? It's a fuck-fest, Roy.

question: Don't talk to me like that, Sara. I thought you were goin' to your friend's house after school. Obviously, you changed your mind. So I'm sorry. Alright?
answer: Sorry you got caught.

question: Sorry I got... observed It's nobody's 'fault.' It's over. Let it be over. We're all adults.
answer: Really? How often do you have it?

question: I got it.
answer: Medicine Man. You know Tute.

question: Actually, I call it a car wash. The work I do, yeah, that's a job. You hangin' with him now? Think that's a good idea, 'Kai?
answer: You got a better one?

question: You could try layin' all this shit off for awhile. Give yourself a chance on the other side.
answer: What other side?

question: You know what I mean. It ain't like you don't have good sense.
answer: I got sense enough to know who I am, what I can do and where I can do it. I ain't like you. People don't just up and hand me shit.

question: Do I detect a 'but'? I know you're -- how do you put it? -- Large here, Nikki. You enjoy that and it's fine for now. I guess. But you can't live your life like a popularity contest.
answer: I don't think it's realistic, what you're asking. Things happen. Things change. And the changes change you. What's the point of plans?

question: To have a sense of direction.
answer: You can't direct destiny.

question: I see here that you trained for Juilliard, that you auditioned.
answer: That was a long time ago.

question: It was three months ago, Sara. Well, if you're not going to pursue dance, what are you going to do?
answer: I don't know. Take a year off. Work. Go to college later on.

question: Feel the groove. Don't let the music mess with you.
answer: Did you always want to be a doctor?

question: Who said I wanna be a doctor?
answer: Chenille. Everybody.

question: Keep it tight. Watch your butt.
answer: What kind of doctor do you want to be?

question: Pediatrics. I like kids. Come on, stay with me. You're slackin'.
answer: Do you have any? Kids.

question: No. Do you?
answer: I wasn't being smart, Patrick.

question: Wouldn't be the first time.
answer: Screw you. I'm brilliant. I didn't get it. That thing you just did. Show me again?

question: What was that shit you just did?
answer: A releve. Over ice. With a twist. Ballet. I used to dance, Patrick.

question: You used to dance?
answer: Uh-huh. Used to as in don't any more. And don't ask me why.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I don't want to talk about it.

question: That's why you brought it up. Did that whole relieve thing. 'Cause you don't wanna talk about it?
answer: Because it's not a big deal. Can we just concentrate on this?

question: Yeah, we can concentrate. But I think it is a big deal. Whatever it is you don't wanna talk about.
answer: I have met somebody. Sort of. I think. I mean, there's this guy...

question: Why's he do that?
answer: He's a baby. They cry.

question: He was screaming, Chenille.
answer: He don't know you, Kenny.

question: I'm his father. He knows me. ... What should I do?
answer: Come around more often.

question: See? I can't talk to you.
answer: And I can't depend on you! Am I askin' you to do anything for him you ain't supposed to do?

question: You don't ask, Chenille. You make demands. You want money, you --
answer: -- I want you to pick up some of the slack. You always have an excuse.

question: It's not like that. I get tied up.
answer: You wanna talk about tied up? Try gettin' up in the middle of the night to change diapers and give him bottles or stayin' up with him when he's sick and havin' to drag your ass to school the next day.

question: Look. I'm doin' the best I can.
answer: It ain't good enough, Kenny!

question: Didn't you like it when you 'used' to dance?
answer: Yeah I liked it. I was gonna go to Juilliard. That school fucked up my entire life. It's a long story.

question: Let me guess. You don't wanna talk about it. I stole a bike here once.
answer: Why'd you do that?

question: 'Cause I didn't have one.
answer: That's a good reason.

question: I used to do wild shit like that.
answer: You and Malakai?

question: Yep. Most of the time.
answer: I don't get you guys. You seem so... different.

question: We're not.
answer: Maybe you weren't then but you are now. You said you changed.

question: Doesn't make me different from him. Not the way you think it does.
answer: I think Malakai's scary. And I know you're not.

question: What you mean by scary? 'Kai's tough. He has to be. He still got a good heart. I know.
answer: Patrick.

question: Let me finish. Me and him got into some shit awhile back. Real bad shit. We held up a gas station off 95. I bailed the ride -- jumped out the car. 'Kai kept goin', got caught. I knew what he was gonna do that night. Knew the car was hot. I woulda been guilty as him if they had caught me, if Malakai had served my name up. But he didn't.
answer: That means you owe him something?

question: He did his time plus most of mine. I owe him that.
answer: No matter how much he messes up?

question: We all mess up. Maybe Malakai gave up. But he's still m'boy and he still got a chance. I ain't just gonna cross him completely off and be like everybody else.
answer: I stole a hat once. When I was twelve. My mom found it under my mattress, made me take it back.

question: Gangsta' Sara. Stole a hat. Call the F.B.I.
answer: You gonna turn me in?

question: I think I'll wait for you to surrender. Were you tight with your mom, Sara? I mean, y'all get along and shit?
answer: Yeah...tight... got along and shit

question: So she meant something to you. How come you never talk about her?
answer: There's nothing to say.

question: Know why there's nothing to say? Because you don't talk about her. You won't talk about her.
answer: I'm sorry she's dead. God! What do you want me to do? Run through the streets screaming?

question: Why not? If it helps.
answer: Well, it won't. So drop it.

question: And you call Malakai scary.
answer: Are you gonna tell me where we're going? Why is the surprise for me? You're the one with something to celebrate.

question: We can celebrate together.
answer: I wanted to get you something and I couldn't figure out what. It's not much but I hope you like it.

question: I like it. I love it. Thank you.
answer: Wait. There's more. We have an audience. Work with me.

question: Work with you?
answer: Grab something.

question: Surprise... Sara?
answer: I can't. I can't go in.

question: You have to go in. This is where I'm bringing you. The ballet.
answer: I know, but --

question: But what? I thought you would like it.
answer: I did.

question: You ain't actin' like you did.
answer: I'm sorry. I don't want you to think I didn't have a good time tonight, Patrick. I did. But ballet isn't a part of my life anymore.

question: Why not? What happened? You just woke up one day and decided to waste your talent.
answer: How do you know I have talent? Because I did some stupid leg trick.

question: I saw the look on your face when you did it, Sara. The same look I saw tonight. Goofy happy. So if you're gonna tell me somethin' about not dancing, at least tell me somethin' real.
answer: Maybe I don't want it to be real. What I want is to wake up and see my mom. For things to go back to the way they were. When they made sense. When my life made sense. And it's all my fault. She got scraped off the highway for me, for my fucking audition. She was rushing. It was raining. It was raining... ... But she promised to be there. I made her promise. And then I didn't wait for her. I should have but they called my name and I didn't say anything. I just went out and danced. I was mad. I needed her and she wasn't there. She was dying while I was dancing and I was mad at her and I'm sorry. I'm sorry...

question: It's not your fault it rained or she died. Or that you danced. That's what you were there for. Your mom would've expected you to do what you did.
answer: That's what makes it so bad. She always did what was right for me. I wanted to be a prima ballerina -- had to be. Even if it took most of our money, all of her spare time. I didn't care. It was my stupid dream and it killed her. All she wanted was for it to come true.

question: You still got whatever you had when your mom was alive, Sara. She wouldn't want you to give up.
answer: I know... but she... I just don't think I can do it without her.

question: Do you want to do it, Sara? I mean you. Do you want Juilliard?
answer: Yeah. I do.

question: Then it's on you to make the dream come true.
answer: Yeah. For my mom.

question: For her. For you.
answer: See you tomorrow?

question: Lemme see that move you did. That cute leg relieve thing. Come on, Sara.
answer: It hurts! I'm out of shape and it hurts. Okay? Satisfied?

question: That's what you call outta shape, what's it take to get you in shape?
answer: Practice.

question: This is the perfect spot for that. You can run around and I can sit under the trees and watch you.
answer: I don't get in shape like that. But it's still a good spot. I got my application for Juilliard. Just in time too. They're holding auditions in Baltimore next month.

question: That's great!
answer: I'll never be ready in a month.

question: Sara, you puttin' the mojo on yourself.
answer: Mojo?

question: Negative shit. White folks call it karma. The bad kind.
answer: You don't understand. Ballet takes a lot of time, a lot of preparation. I used to practice two, three hours every day. I'm so far behind...

question: Quit whinin' and catch up then.
answer: It's not as easy as that. My free form still sucks. It's still the weakest part of my routine. That hasn't changed.

question: So I'll help you with it.
answer: You will?

question: Yeah. I'll help you. Tell me what you need to do and let's get busy.
answer: Let's skip. Later.

question: He's in D.C. Blues Alley. He'll be gone all night. Roy's demo. The only one he ever cut. Kinda grows on you. Wanna see my room? Sorry...
answer: Whatever you do, don't fuck him.

question: Excuse me?
answer: 'Hit it and quit it,' that's their motto.

question: Whose motto?
answer: Black guys. Everybody knows that.

question: Y'all hangin' tonight or what?
answer: We thinkin' about slidin' through that new rec center opened up on the Eastside. You ridin'?

question: Eastside? That's the wrong side. I ain't messin' with those fools over there. You know how they are.
answer: I ain't pressed. I got my own shit. What you think? I'ma keep walkin' around waitin' for some chump to cap me? I'ma protect myself.

question: That ain't protection. It's an excuse for some unnecessary mayhem.
answer: Ain't nothin' unnecessary 'bout it. Shit. Mayhem and madness. That's a black man's life.

question: How you know? You ain't tried nothing else. Now you sittin' up here strapped for no good reason. You askin' for trouble, Malakai. You think this shit's funny?
answer: I think it's funny you think it ain't necessary. You act like you don't know where you are no more, Patrick, and whassup out there for anybody who ain't you. Maybe that's what happens when a white girl goes to your head.

question: Fuck you, Lip. I know what's out there. I also know you can get past it. But that ain't gonna happen, 'Kai, long as you keep gettin' in your own way. What's your favorite flower?
answer: I don't have a favorite.

question: Yeah, but if you did...
answer: I dunno. Maybe cymbidiums -- orchids. They're sort of show- boaty but they're pretty.

question: What's your favorite color?
answer: Agua.

question: What's your second favorite color?
answer: Mmm. Mauve.

question: You're makin' this real hard, Sara. Those ain't exactly tuxedo colors.
answer: Nut. What are you talking about?

question: Who the hell are you to tell me how to come off? You're in my house alone with my daughter.
answer: I hate being your daughter. You ruin everything.

question: Siddown. It's a free country, you can hate me. Ain't like that's exactly news. But disrespectin' me, that's where the road ends, Sara. I don't want him up here again. I mean it.
answer: You mean it because he's black.

question: Don't start that bullshit!
answer: Why's it bullshit? Because you hang with black guys and play jazz and have the hots for Angela Bassett?

question: Because he was in my house with his hands all over my daughter!
answer: Keep telling yourself that. Just don't expect me to believe it. I saw how you looked at him. But you didn't see him. Well, for your information, he's a straight- A student with more heart and guts than you'll ever have!

question: Yeah? Well, when are you gonna have the guts to say what you really want to say to me, Sara?
answer: Want me to say it? You were a piece of shit husband and you're a piece of shit father! You were never there for Mom or for me. You took off and never looked back. So don't talk to me about guts.

question: Sounds like you have it all figured out.
answer: I have you figured out. You think you can make up all the time you missed, all the things you didn't do? You can't! I'm here because I have to be and it's a goddamned nightmare.

question: Well, you might as well wake up and get used to it, Sara, because that's the way things are sometimes, the way life is.
answer: How the hell would you know? You've been asleep for the past thirty-seven years!

question: The 'Love Boat.'
answer: Love shit. That bitch is tap- dancin' on my last nerve.

question: Looks like she's tap-dancing on your last boyfriend. She got it like that? Naw. Never mind. Stall it. I ain't heard shit.
answer: Stall what? What you hear?

question: Some trash she's talkin'. About you.
answer: About me?

question: Yeah. How you ain't all 'at since Patrick's takin' her to the prom. I am a little bit... chagrined though, Nikki. You lettin' some white ho' show you up like that.
answer: Fuck you, Malakai. Fuck her too.

question: Diondre, what your butt doin' here? Whatever it is, I don't wanna hear it.
answer: I thought you had somethin' to say to me.

question: You thought wrong.
answer: Somethin' must be on your mind for you to get up in Sara's face, start all this drama. What you tryin' to prove, Nikki?

question: You're the one tryin' to prove something. Stuck up in her shit like she's somethin' special.
answer: What if she is? What's it to you? You didn't see me trippin' off that Howard dude and I could have. I coulda tripped hard, Nikki.

question: That was different.
answer: How you gonna call it different?

question: Because she's white and he ain't. And don't sit there like you don't know what I'm talkin' about, Patrick.
answer: You don't even know what you're talkin' about, Nikki.

question: I don't? Y'all black men, soon as you even think about goin' someplace good, first thing you do is find a white girl to take with you.
answer: I thought I was goin' someplace good with you. You the one called me off. But you ain't tryin' to remember that. Now you mad. Why? Because she's white and I like her? I'm with her.

question: Please. You're with her because she's white. That's what sets me off.
answer: It ain't got no business settin' you off! Me and her ain't got nothin' to do with you and what you think. So keep your hands off her and that shit to yourself.

question: What? I'm supposed to get excited because you decided to skate by and drop a dollar on the dresser?
answer: It's more than a dollar. And it's all I got. I got laid off rom B.W.I., Chenille. I been workin' part- time. Money's tight. You know how you are about money. That's way I haven't been coming around.

question: Money ain't got nothin' to do with it, Kenny. You don't come around because you don't feel like comin' around. You don't want the responsibility of comin' around. As long as you out there and I'm in here, you know your son's being taken care of. You ain't got no worries when it comes to him.
answer: And you don't have no feelings when it comes to me. All you do is bitch and complain about what I don't do. I get sick of that.

question: Be sick of it. You ain't got to see me to see your son.
answer: I'll be sure to keep that in mind.

question: Want me to take him?
answer: That wench. You gotta stand over her to make sure she puts your name on the damn list. Triflin' bitch.

question: I'll get 'em.
answer: So your old man flipped about the fight. Probably thinks it's all Patrick's fault.

question: No. I explained about Nikki.
answer: Right. You put it all on her. None of it's on you.

question: She started it, Chenille. She wanted to start it. I told you what she said.
answer: Maybe she didn't have no business gettin' in your face. But she had a reason to say what she said.

question: So you agree with her? You think I don't belong with Patrick.
answer: What I think don't matter. But you and him act like it don't bother people that you're together. Like it don't hurt people to see.

question: We like each other. What is the big fucking deal? It's him and me. Not us and other 'people.'
answer: Black people, Sara. Black women. Patrick's about somethin'. He's smart. He's motivated. He's for real. He ain't gonna make no babies and not take care of 'em or run the streets, fuck up his life. He's gonna do somethin' with himself. Here you come, white and right, and you take one of the few decent men left after jail, drugs and drive-bys. That's what Nikki meant about you up in our world.

question: So what you gonna do?
answer: How many times you gonna ask me that?

question: It's payback time. Either you down or you ain't. Either you m'boy or you not. Simple as that.
answer: Even if I did ride, you ain't got nobody but Lip and Lip will get a nigger's ass killed. Quick.

question: We should keep going.
answer: You messed up.

question: I know I messed up. I'll get it right the next time.
answer: No. You gonna get it right now so you can do it perfect next time.

question: I can't work like this. I can't dance like this.
answer: Like what?

question: Like this. You dictating to me.
answer: What's wrong, Sara?

question: Nothing's wrong. I can't figure things out.
answer: What things? The audition? You ain't got nothin' to worry about. I told you. I'll be there.

question: Things, Patrick. Things between us. Things between us and them.
answer: I didn't know there was a 'them.'

question: Well, open your pretty brown eyes, look the hell around. Everything's screwed up. Nobody wants to see us together, not even Chenille. I don't know why they feel that way. How can I know? Maybe they have a point, Patrick.
answer: They only got a point if you believe they got a point, Sara.

question: I'm just saying that we should think about this, that's all.
answer: That's a fuckin' 'nough.

question: Why are you getting mad?
answer: Because I like to think for myself, run my own life, and I thought you did too.

question: You're never gonna run your own life as long as you keep running back to Malakai every time he fucks up or fucks you over.
answer: First of all, Malakai ain't never fucked me over. Second of all, you don't know him, Sara, what he been through. Matter of fact, you don't know shit about none of it. So don't come off to me like you do.

question: I know he's lost, Patrick! Everybody but you can see that. And if you keep reaching back for him, you're gonna wind up lost too.
answer: Who the fuck are you to say he's lost? Malakai had my back when you were busy gee-whizzin' in the woods with your backward-ass, redneck friends.

question: They weren't rednecks!
answer: You know what? The hell with you.

question: The hell with you too! Hi.
answer: Thought you might need this on Saturday. I ain't gonna be able to make it.

question: Toni, listen carefully. You're a simple bitch and you don't have any friends, black or white, because nobody likes a fucking asshole.
answer: I was wondering... how long you plan on hating me? Maybe I'm an optimist but I hope there's some kind of timetable. Well, I don't wanna bug you. I just came in to say good luck. I saw the return address. Got curious. It was open. I read it. I know I shouldn't have but at least now I have an excuse to tell you how proud I am of you, Sara.

question: I was gonna tell you about the audition, Roy. I meant to.
answer: Tomorrow's the big day?

question: Uh-huh. The big day.
answer: You bummed out about it? You're a worse liar than I am father.

question: You're not so bad. I didn't give you much to work with. It's not like I've been the perfect daughter.
answer: Well, it ain't like I deserve a perfect daughter. I screwed up. Did everything in a hurry and still thought I had all the time in the world. To be in love with your mother. Be a father to you. But time flies. You look up one day and all you got to show for yourself is a pretty little girl who hates your guts and won't talk to you because too much time went by.

question: I don't hate you. I miss her. I miss Mom... ... Patrick's pissed at me. I'm pissed at him. He's not coming tomorrow and I want him there and I don't know what to do.
answer: You want him there. I understand that. But whatever he brings to the table, Patrick can't dance for you, Sara. You're the bottom line out there. This is your chance to be the dancer Juilliard came to see.

question: I wanted somebody there who loves me.
answer: I love you.

question: Malakai... ... When it's on, I'll be there.
answer: Why you so quiet? Patrick Reynolds ain't got nothin' to say? That's a first. You know how I go off on folks sometimes. I mean it and then I don't mean it. Like what I said to Sara. Guess she told you.

question: I don't care what you said, Chenille.
answer: Patrick. Your ass is on your back and your lips are on the ground. You care, baby brother. And not just about what I said. You seriously like Sara. She got a serious jones for you. Am I lyin'?

question: It's besides the point. Whatever point it is you tryin' to make.
answer: I'm sayin' you can't help who you love, Patrick. At least you found somebody who loves you back.

question: I gotta go.
answer: To where? To who? Malakai? You ain't through with that fool yet.

question: He's not a fool, Chenille.
answer: No. You know what? You're the fool, Patrick. You think you let Malakai down and all you did was try to pull yourself up. Ain't no blame or shame in that.

question: It cut me, what you said.
answer: I shouldn't have... I was trippin'.

question: You always trip. I'm used to that. Besides, you were right. You were wrong, too. So was I. I need to do better. Ain't no doubt about that.
answer: I know I come down on you hard about money, but I would rather you spend the time. Seriously.

question: So you don't want any money?
answer: I didn't say all that.

question: I love my son, Chenille. You know that, don't you?
answer: Yeah. I always knew that.

question: finishes with a flawless arabesque. Looks out.
answer: You prepared a free-form?

question: Yes... sir... they have... my music. Yes. Emo... Emotion.
answer: Cue Johnson's music.

question: stands there. Doesn't move. Can't. She finally walks up to the edge of the stage. Looks down at the judges, her eyes filled with trepidation. Her voice is a shaky whisper. I'm sorry. I wasn't ready. Can you start it over again?
answer: Are you ready now?
